section:
System Calls
The &posix-pac; module makes some system calls available from lisp. Not all of these system calls are actually &posix;, so this package has a nickname OS. If the package prefix is not specified below, the symbol resides in this package. &base-module; When this module is present, &features-my; contains the symbol :SYSCALLS.
Networking
(&resolve-host; &optional-amp; &host-r;)
Returns the HOSTENT structure: name host name aliases &list-t; of aliases addr-list &list-t; of &ip; addresses as dotted quads (for IPv4) or coloned octets (for IPv6) addrtype &integer-t; address type (IPv4 or IPv6)
When &host-r; is omitted or &default-k;, return the data for the current host. When &host-r; is &nil;, all the host database is returned as a list (this would be the contents of the /etc/hosts file on a &unix; system or ${windir}/system32/etc/hosts on a &win32; system). This is an interface to gethostent, gethostbyname, and gethostbyaddr.
(OS:SERVICE &optional-amp; service-name &proto-r;) A convenience function for looking up a port given the service name, such as WWW or FTP. It returns the SERVICE structure (name, list of aliases, port, protocol) for the given service-name and &proto-r;, or all services as a &list-t; if service-name is missing or &nil;.This is an interface to getservent, getservbyname, and getservbyport.
File system
(POSIX:FILE-STAT &path-r; &optional-amp; link-p)
Return the FILE-STAT structure. &path-r; can be a &stream-t;, a &pathname-t;, a &string-t; or a &number-t; (on a &unix; system, meaning &file-des;). The first slot of the structure returned is the string or the number on which stat, &fstat;, or lstat was called. The other slots are numbers, members of the struct stat:
dev Device ID of device containing file.
ino File serial number.
mode Mode of file.
nlink Number of hard links to the file.
uid User ID of file.
gid Group ID of file.
rdev Device ID (if file is character or block special). size For regular files, the file size in bytes. For symbolic links, the length in bytes of the pathname contained in the symbolic link. For a shared memory object, the length in bytes. For a typed memory object, the length in bytes. For other file types, the use of this field is unspecified.
atime &uni-time; of last access.
mtime &uni-time; of last data modification.
ctime &uni-time; of last status change (on &win32; - creation time). blksize A file system-specific preferred I/O block size for this object. In some file system types, this may vary from file to file. blocks Number of blocks allocated for this object.
All slots are read-only. If the system does not support a particular field (e.g., &win32; prior to 2000 does not have hard links), &nil; (or the default, like 1 for the number of hard links for old &win32;) is returned. &win32-only;
Normally, one would expect (POSIX:FILE-STAT "foo") and (POSIX:FILE-STAT (&open; "foo")) to return similar objects (&open;ing a file changes its access time though). This is &not-e; the case on &win32;, where stat works but &fstat; does &not-e;. Specifically, &fstat; requires an int argument of an unknown nature, and it is not clear how do deduce it from the &win32; file handle. Therefore, instead of always failing on open &file-stream-t; arguments, this function calls GetFileInformationByHandle and fills the FILE-STAT return value based on that.
(POSIX:SET-FILE-STAT &path-r; &key-amp; :ATIME :MTIME :MODE :UID :GID) Set some file attributes using chmod, chown, and utime.
(POSIX:STAT-VFS &path-r;)
Return a STAT-VFS structure. &path-r; can be a &stream-t;, a &pathname-t;, a &string-t; or a &number-t; (on a &unix; system, meaning &file-des;). The first slot of the structure returned is the string or the number on which statvfs or fstatvfs was called. The other slots are members of the struct statvfs:
bsize File system block size.
frsize Fundamental file system block size.
blocks Total number of blocks on file system in units of frsize. bfree Total number of free blocks.
bavail Number of free blocks available to non-privileged processes. files Total number of file serial numbers.
ffree Total number of free file serial numbers.
favail Number of file serial numbers available to non-privileged processes. fsid File system ID. flag List of platform-dependent values, such as &ro-k;.
namemax Maximum filename length.
vol-name Volume name (&win32; only).
fs-type File system type (&win32; only).
All slots are read-only.
(OS:FILE-INFO &path-r; &optional-amp; all)
Return the FILE-INFO structure. &path-r; should be a &path-des;. The 7 slots are attributes ctime atime wtime size name name-short When &path-r; is wild, returns just the first match, unless the second (optional) argument is non-&nil;, in which case a &list-t; of objects is returned, one for each match.
(POSIX:STREAM-LOCK &stream-r; lock-p &key-amp; (:BLOCK &t;) (:SHARED &nil;) (:START 0) (:END &nil;)) Set or remove a file lock for the (portion of the) file associated with &stream-r;, depending on lock-p. When block is &nil;, the call is non-blocking, and when locking fails, it returns &nil;. When shared is non-&nil;, then lock can be shared between several callers. Several processes can set a shared (i.e., read) lock, but only one can set an exclusive (i.e., write, or non-shared) lock. Uses fcntl or LockFileEx. &unix; and &win32; differ on locking 0-length files: on &win32;, two processes can have exclusive locks on it! &win32; locks are mandatory: if you lock a file, others will not be able to open it! &unix; locks are usually advisory: a process is free to ignore it, but on some &unix; systems one can mount some file system with mandatory locks.
(POSIX:WITH-STREAM-LOCK (&stream-r; &rest-amp; &options-r;) &body-amp; &body-r;) Lock the &stream-r;, execute the &body-r;, unlock the &stream-r;. Pass &options-r; to &stream-lock;.
(&stream-options; &stream-r; &command-r; &optional-amp; &value-r;) Call fcntl, &command-r; can be :FD or :FL.
(&file-size; &file-r;) (&setf; (&file-size; &file-r;) &size-r;) Extend &file-length; to operate on &path-des;s. Set the &size-r; of a &file-r; using ftruncate (if &file-r; is an open &file-stream-t;) or truncate (if &file-r; is a &path-des;). Use SetFilePointerEx and SetEndOfFile on &win32;.
(POSIX:MKNOD &path-r; &type-r; &mode-r;) Create a special file using mknod. Use :FIFO to create pipes and :SOCK to create sockets.
(POSIX:CONVERT-MODE &mode-r;) Convert between numeric, (e.g., 0644) and symbolic (e.g., (:RUSR :WUSR :RGRP :ROTH)) file modes. (POSIX:UMASK &mode-r;) Change process mask using umask.
(&copy-file; &source-r; &dest-r; &key-amp; :METHOD :PRESERVE :IF-EXISTS :IF-DOES-NOT-EXIST) This is an interface to symlink (when &method-r; is :SYMLINK), link (when it is :HARDLINK), and rename (when it is :RENAME) system calls, as well as, you guessed it, a generic file copy utility (when &method-r; is &copy-k;). When &method-r; is :HARDLINK-OR-COPY and link fails (e.g., because the &source-r; and &dest-r; are on different devices), fall back to &copy-k;. Both &source-r; and &dest-r; may be wild, in which case &translate-pathname; is used. The meaning and defaults of &if-exists; and &if-does-not-exist; are the same as in &open;.
(&dup-handle; fd1 &optional-amp; fd2) This is an interface to the &dup; system calls on &unix; systems and to DuplicateHandle system call on &win32;. (OS:SHORTCUT-INFO &path-r;) Return information about a &win32; shortcut (#P".lnk") file contents in a SHORTCUT-INFO structure. (OS:MAKE-SHORTCUT &path-r; &key-amp; :WORKING-DIRECTORY :ARGUMENTS :SHOW-COMMAND :ICON :DESCRIPTION :HOT-KEY :PATH) Create (or modify the properties of an existing one) a &win32; shortcut (#P".lnk") file.
(OS:FILE-PROPERTIES filename set &key-amp; :INITID &allow-other-keys-amp;)
Wrapper for the &win32; IPropertyStorage functionality. &filename-r; name of a compound file (where properties are stored) or (on NTFS) name of any file (properties are stored in the filesystem). For compound files on NTFS, file storage is preferred.
set property set, either :BUILT-IN or :USER-DEFINED
:INITID init-id set the init-id
specifier value
specifier
the property specifier: an &integer-t;, &keyword-t;, &string-t; or a &list-t; of an &integer-t; or a &keyword-t; and a &string-t;. &integer-t; a property identifier
&keyword-t;
Predefined &keyword-t; IDs are
:APPNAME :AUTHOR :CHARCOUNT :CODEPAGE :COMMENTS :CREATE-DTM :DOC-SECURITY :EDITTIME :KEYWORDS :LASTAUTHOR :LASTPRINTED :LASTSAVE-DTM :LOCALE :PAGECOUNT :REVNUMBER :SUBJECT :TEMPLATE :THUMBNAIL :TITLE :WORDCOUNT
&string-t; string property specifier. If no match is found, the first ID >= init-id (which defaults to 2) is associated with the string and its value is replaced with new value.
(&integer-t;|&keyword-t; &string-t;) the first element is used as a specifier, the string is associated with this ID.
&value-r;
the new value of the property, a suitable Lisp object, &nil; or a &list-t; of a &keyword-t; and the value itself. If &value-r; is &nil;, no assignment is done. :EMPTY and :NULL correspond to the VT_EMPTY and VT_NULL data types. &keyword-t; in the &list-t; specifies the desired type of the property being set. Supported types are :BOOL :BSTR :DATE :ERROR :FILETIME :I1 :I2 :I4 :I8 :LPSTR :LPWSTR :R4 :R8 :UI1 :UI2 :UI4 :UI8 :UINT FILETIMEs are converted to/from the universal time format, while DATEs are not.
Returns the property contents before assignment as multiple values.
(OS:FILE-OWNER &filename-r;) Return the owner of the file. &unix-w32-only; (POSIX:MKSTEMP &filename-r; &key-amp; &direction-k; &eltype; &extfmt; &buffered;) Calls &mkstemp;, returns a &file-stream-t;. &direction-k; should allow output. When &mkstemp; is missing, use tempnam. On &win32; use GetTempFileName.
(POSIX:MKDTEMP &filename-r;) Calls mkdtemp (similar to &mkstemp; but not in &posix;), returns the namestring of a new empty temporary directory.
(POSIX:SYNC &optional-amp; &stream-r;) Calls fsync (FlushFileBuffers on &win32;) on the &file-des; associated with &stream-r;, or sync when &stream-r; is not supplied
Users and Groups
(POSIX:USER-INFO &optional-amp; &user-r;) Return the USER-INFO structure (name, encoded password, UID, GID, full name, home directory, shell). &user-r; should be a &string-t; (getpwnam is used) or an &integer-t; (getpwuid is used). When &user-r; is missing or &nil;, return all users (using getpwent). When &user-r; is &default-k;, return the information about the current user (using getlogin). &unix-only; (POSIX:GROUP-INFO &optional-amp; group) Return the GROUP-INFO structure (name, GID, member &list-t;). group should be a &string-t; (getgrnam is used) or an &integer-t; (getgrgid is used). When group is missing or &nil;, return all groups (using getgrent). &unix-only; (POSIX:USER-SHELLS) Call getusershell.
(OS:GET-USER-SID &optional-amp; &user-r;) Call LookupAccountName on &user-r; or, if that is not supplied, call OpenProcessToken GetTokenInformation, and then ConvertSidToStringSid on User.Sid.
System Information
(POSIX:UNAME) Return a structure describing the OS, derived from uname. (POSIX:SYSCONF &optional-amp; &what-r;) (POSIX:CONFSTR &optional-amp; &what-r;) Return the specified configuration parameter or a &plist; of all available parameters (when &what-r; is missing or &nil;), by calling sysconf and confstr respectively.
(POSIX:PATHCONF &path-r; &optional-amp; &what-r;) Return the specified configuration parameter or a &plist; of all available parameters (when &what-r; is missing or &nil;), by calling fpathconf on open file streams and pathconf on all other &path-des;s. (&rlimit; &optional-amp; &what-r;) Return the current and the maximal limits as two values when &what-r; is specified or the &alist; of all available limits (as an RLIMIT structure) when &what-r; is missing or &nil;, by calling getrlimit.
(&setf; (&rlimit; &what-r;) (&values; cur max)) (&setf; (&rlimit; &what-r;) rlimit) (&setf; (&rlimit;) rlimit-alist)
Set the limits using setrlimit. In the first form, cur and max are numbers (or &nil; for RLIM_INFINITY). In the second form, rlimit is an RLIMIT structure. In the third form, rlimit-alist is an &alist;, as returned by (&rlimit;).
(POSIX:USAGE) Return 2 structures describing the resource usage by the lisp process and its children, using getrusage.
(POSIX:BOGOMIPS) Compute the BogoMips rating. (POSIX:LOADAVG &optional-amp; percentp) Return 1, 5, and 15 minute system load averages, retrieved by getloadavg. If the argument is specified and non-&nil;, the values are returned as integer percentiles. (OS:SYSTEM-INFO) Return &win32; system information in a SYSTEM-INFO structure. (OS:VERSION) Return &win32; version information in a VERSION structure. (OS:MEMORY-STATUS) Return &win32; memory status information in a MEMORY-STATUS structure. (OS:PHYSICAL-MEMORY) Return 2 values: total and available physical memory. &unix-w32-only; (OS:HOSTID) (&setf; (OS:HOSTID) &value-r;) Call gethostid and return a (hopefully) universally unique &integer-t; identifier of this machine.
On &linux; this number appears to be the IPv4 32-bit address with the first 2 bytes and the last 2 bytes swapped: (&convert-address; :inet (os:hostid)) "7.3.192.168" (first (posix:hostent-addr-list (&resolve-host; :default))) "192.168.7.3"This, of course, means that universally unique it is &not-e;. Superuser can also set host identifier using &setf; which calls sethostid. &unix-w32-only; (OS:DOMAINNAME) (&setf; (OS:DOMAINNAME) &dom-r;) Call getdomainname and setdomainname.
Mathematical functions
We implement access to (erf &real-r;) (erfc &real-r;) (j0 &real-r;) (j1 &real-r;) (jn &int-r; &real-r;) (y0 &real-r;) (y1 &real-r;) (yn &int-r; &real-r;) (tgamma &real-r;) (lgamma &real-r;) which compute the error functions, Bessel functions and Gamma. These functions are required by the &posix; standard and should be declared in math.h. Please note that these functions do &not-e; provide lisp-style error handling and precision, and do all the computations at the &double-float-t; level.
Function (ffs &n-r;) finds the first bit set. It is implemented in pure Lisp and supports &bignum-t;s.
Encryption
(POSIX:CRYPT &key-r; salt) Call crypt, arguments are &string-t;s.
(POSIX:ENCRYPT block decrypt-p) (POSIX:SETKEY &key-r;) Call encrypt and setkey, respectively. block and &key-r; are of type (&vector; (&unsigned-byte-t; 8) 8). decrypt-p is &boolean-t;.
Syslog
(POSIX:OPENLOG ident &key-amp; :PID :CONS :NDELAY :ODELAY :NOWAIT :FACILITY) Calls openlog
(POSIX:SETLOGMASK maskpri) Calls setlogmask.
(POSIX:SYSLOG severity facility &fmt-r; &rest-amp; &args-r;) Calls syslog on (&apply; &format; &nil; &fmt-r; &args-r;). No % conversion is performed, you must do all formatting in Lisp. (POSIX:CLOSELOG) Calls closelog.
Processes
(OS:PROCESS-ID) Return the process ID (on &unix; calls getpid, on &win32; calls GetCurrentProcessId)
(OS:PRIORITY &pid-r; &optional-amp; &what-r;) (&setf; (OS:PRIORITY &pid-r; &optional-amp; &what-r;) priority)
Return or set the process priority, platform-dependent &integer-t; or platform-independent &symbol-t;, one of
:REALTIME :HIGH :ABOVE-NORMAL :NORMAL :BELOW-NORMAL :LOW :IDLE On &unix; calls getpriority and setpriority, on &win32; calls GetPriorityClass and SetPriorityClass.
(POSIX:KILL &pid-r; &sig-r;) Calls kill.
(POSIX:GETPPID) Calls getppid.
(POSIX:GETPGRP) Calls getpgrp.
(POSIX:SETPGRP) Calls setpgrp; on non-&posix; systems where it requires 2 arguments (legacy BSD-style), it is called as setpgrp(0,0).
(POSIX:GETSID &pid-r;) Calls getsid.
(POSIX:SETSID) Calls setsid.
(POSIX:PGID &pid-r;) (&setf; (POSIX:PGID &pid-r;) pgid) Call getpgid and setpgid. (POSIX:SETREUID ruid euid) Call setreuid.
(POSIX:SETREGID rgid egid) Call setregid.
(POSIX:UID) (&setf; (POSIX:UID) &uid-r;) Call getuid and setuid. (POSIX:GID) (&setf; (POSIX:GID) &gid-r;) Call getgid and setgid. (POSIX:EUID) (&setf; (POSIX:EUID) &uid-r;) Call geteuid and seteuid. (POSIX:EGID) (&setf; (POSIX:EGID) &gid-r;) Call getegid and setegid. (POSIX:GROUPS) (&setf; (POSIX:GROUPS) &list-r;) Call getgroups and setgroups.
(POSIX:WAIT &key-amp; :PID :USAGE :NOHANG :UNTRACED :STOPPED :EXITED :CONTINUED :NOWAIT) Wait for termination of the child process :PID (or any child process if not specified). If :NOHANG is specifed, return &zero; as the only value immediately if no child process has terminated. Otherwise, the first return value is the &pid-r; of the terminated child process.
The second and third return values depend on the way the process terminated: 2nd value = :EXITED 3rd value = exit status if the child terminated normally, e.g., by calling exit.
2nd value = :SIGNALED 3rd value = &sig-r; if the child process was terminated by a &sig-r;.
2nd value = :STOPPED 3rd value = &sig-r; if the child process was stopped by delivery of a &sig-r;. 2nd value = :CONTINUED 3rd value = &nil; if the child process has continued from a job control stop. 2nd value = &nil; 3rd value = &number-r; if &clisp; could not figure out what has happened. Please read your local waitpid manual and send us a patch.
The fourth value is only returned if :USAGE is non-&nil; and in that case it is a structure describing resource usage by the terminated process, similar to what USAGE returns. Calls waitpid and (when :USAGE is non-&nil;) wait4.
Accounting
(POSIX:ENDUTXENT) Calls endutxent.
(POSIX:GETUTXENT &optional-amp; utmpx) Calls getutxent, returns a &structure-object-t; of type POSIX:UTMPX, which can be passed to subsequent calls to this function and re-used. (POSIX:GETUTXID id) Calls getutxid, the argument is filled and returned. (POSIX:GETUTXLINE line) Calls getutxline, the argument is filled and returned. (POSIX:PUTUTXLINE utmpx) Calls pututxline, the argument is filled and returned. (POSIX:SETUTXENT) Calls setutxent.
Time conversion
(OS:STRING-TIME &fmt-r; &optional-amp; &object-r; timezone) When &object-r; is a &string-t;, is is parsed according to &fmt-r; by strptime. When it is an &integer-t;, it is formatted according to &fmt-r; by strftime. &object-r; defaults to (&get-universal-time;).
String comparision
Functions (OS:VERSION< &x1-r; &x2-r;) (OS:VERSION<= &x1-r; &x2-r;) (OS:VERSION> &x1-r; &x2-r;) (OS:VERSION>= &x1-r; &x2-r;) compare two &string-t;s as version numbers (e.g., "foo10" is greater than "foo9") using strverscmp and return a &boolean-t;.
Function OS:VERSION-COMPARE does the same but returns either <, > or =.
XTerm
(&mk-xterm-io; &key-amp; title xterm) When running under the &X;, you can create a &bidi-s;, which uses a new dedicated text window (created by the executable specified by the :XTERM argument which should be compatible with xterm and rxvt, i.e., accept options -n, -T, and -e) using the function &mk-xterm-io;: (&setq; &error-output-var; (&setq; &debug-io-var; (&mk-xterm-io; :title "clisp errors and debug"))) &unix-only;
Standard file input and output
We define the type FFI:file = &foreign-pointer-t; and the following functions: (fopen &filename-r; &mode-r;) (fdopen fd &mode-r;) (freopen &filename-r; &mode-r; &file-r;) (fclose &file-r;) (fflush &file-r;)
(clearerr &file-r;) (feof &file-r;) (ferror &file-r;) (fileno &file-r;) call their namesakes defined in &stdio;.
Functions OS:FOPEN OS:FDOPEN OS:FREOPEN OS:FCLOSE OS:FFLUSH OS:FILENO may &signal; an &error-t;. Return values OS:FOPEN OS:FDOPEN FFI:file = &foreign-pointer-t;
OS:FREOPEN OS:FCLOSE OS:FFLUSH OS:CLEARERR no values (they modify their &file-r; argument in place)
OS:FEOF OS:FERROR &boolean-t; OS:FILENO &integer-t; (&file-des;)
We also define 3 constants OS:STDIN OS:STDOUT OS:STDERR
This functionality is &not-e; for i/o, but merely for for &ffi-pac; modules which interface to functions which use the &c-lang; FILE* pointers. E.g., &postgresql-mod; has a function PQtrace which expects a FILE* argument. You can use OS:FOPEN and OS:FCLOSE for that. This functionality is only present if &ffi-pac; is present.
Error handling
To handle errors in foreign functions, the following two functions are provided: (OS:ERRNO &optional-amp; &ecode-r;) When &ecode-r; (a number or a keyword) is supplied, &errno; is set (useful before a system call which sets &errno; as the only way to report an error). The current &errno; is returned as a keyword if possible, a number otherwise. When &ecode-r; is &t;, all known error codes are returned as an &alist;. On &win32;, GetLastError and SetLastError are used instead of &errno;. (OS:STRERROR &optional-amp; &ecode-r;) Return a string description of &ecode-r;. When &ecode-r; is not supplied, &errno; (GetLastError on &win32;) is used. This calls &strerror; on &unix; and FormatMessage on &win32;.
This functionality is only present if &ffi-pac; is present.
Miscellanea
(OS:CLIPBOARD) (&setf; (OS:CLIPBOARD) &object-r;) Get (using GetClipboardData) a set (using SetClipboardData) the windows clipboard. Return a &string-t;; convert &object-r; to a &string-t; using &princ-to-string;. &win32-cygwin-only;
